did.head: Collection Summary

corpname.part: Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Manuscript materials, including programs, newspaper clippings, handbills, programs, small posters, and black-and-white photographs, documenting Swapping Song Fair, a folk music production company and concert series founded in New York City in 1955 by Lou Gordon and Paddy Clancy, which produced a Musical Tribute to Woody Guthrie in 1956, and Folk Song '59. The collection documents musical and other events in the folk music revival in New York City during the 1950s.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Marcia K. Segal.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lou Gordon collection (AFC 2010/031), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Notes
bioghist.p: Louis H. Gordon was a union organizer, harmonica player, and folk music producer. He and Patrick (Paddy) Clancy formed Swapping Song Fair in 1955, a folk music production company that staged concerts in New York City Town Hall and Carnegie Hall and other venues. He served as a sergeant with the Combat Engineers in the 7th Army in Europe during World War II. He was a trustee of the Woody Guthrie Children's Trust Fund; was born in 1915 in Brooklyn, New York; married to Anne Gordon; and died March 25, 2006 at his home in Millbrook, New York.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

subject.part: Folk musicians--New York (State)--New York--Social life and customs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Manuscript materials, including programs, newspaper clippings, handbills, programs, small posters, and black-and-white photographs, documenting Swapping Song Fair, a folk music production company and concert series founded in New York City in 1955 by Lou Gordon and Paddy Clancy, which produced "A Musical Tribute to Woody Guthrie" in 1956, and Folk Song '59. The collection documents musical and other events in the folk music revival in New York City during the 1950s.

did.unittitle: "A brief history of Swapping Song Fair"

scopecontent.p: An overview, written by Anne Gordon.

A photocopied obituary from the
Times Herald-Record.

did.unittitle:
Letter from Cynthia Gooding Ozbekkan to Lou Gordon (photocopy),
April 26, 1954

scopecontent.p: Ozbekkan expresses disappointment that Guy Carawan will performing at a Swapping Song Fair concert.

did.unittitle:
Swapping Song Fair: Folk Songs of Israel,
circa mid-1950s

scopecontent.p: Handbill for the concert, featuring Theodore Bikel and Cynthia Gooding. 2 copies.

Cheques written to various people and organizations from the account of Swapping Song Fair, and signed by Lou Gordon. Drawn on two banks: the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, the First National City Bank of New York, and (later) the National City Bank of New York. Recipients include Jean Ritchie, George Pickow, Oscar Brand, Frank Warner, Trio Productions, Jack Elliott (Ramblin' Jack Elliott), Brownie McGhee, Guy Carawan, Jo Mapes, and others. The cheques have been endorsed by the recipients (or possibly their representatives).
A two-page list of artists and (presumably) the dates scheduled to perform at Swapping Song Fair.

did.unittitle:
Swapping Song Fair: concert program,
November 2, 1956

scopecontent.p: The program also has a copy of the mailed concert announcement. 2 copies of the program and the announcement (total of four items).
Handbills for various Swapping Song Fair concerts.
Newspaper clippings of event calendar listings that included Swapping Song Fair concerts; most of the items are very small, (about 1 in. x 1/2 in.
Small articles in various newspapers announcing upcoming Swapping Song Fair concerts or reviewed events that had taken place.

did.unittitle: Swapping Song Fair: flyer for May events

scopecontent.p: The flyer notes the events have moved from Circle in the Square back to Cherry Lane Theatre.

did.unittitle:
Drawing of a woman,
circa April 13, 1957

scopecontent.p: Pencil drawing by an unidentified artist, on the back of an announcement of a Swapping Song Fair concert featuring Martha Schlamme, held on April 13, 1957.
The March 17, 1966, tribute was presented by Swapping Song Fair.

did.unittitle:
A Musical Tribute to Woody Guthrie: Bound for Glory - handbills,
1956

scopecontent.p: Three copies of the handbill, plus a note from Anne Gordon regarding the concert location.

did.unittitle:
A Musical Tribute to Woody Guthrie: Bound for Glory - ticket,
March 17, 1956

scopecontent.p: An orchestra-seat ticket for the event.

did.unittitle:
A Musical Tribute to Woody Guthrie: Bound for Glory - program and script,
March 17, 1956

scopecontent.p: An original program and a photocopy of the script.

Unsigned memo to Toshi and Pete Seeger, and Lou Gordon, regarding the Conservation Service Award awarded to Woody Guthrie and presented to his family. Typed on the letterhead of the Guthrie Children's Trust Fund, the memo is accompanied by several sheets of the trust fund's letterhead.
Section 2 of the Sunday News (New York), with a cover story about Guthrie.
The Conservation Award given to Guthrie is the focus of the cover story.

did.unittitle:
Woody Guthrie memorial concert: script,
circa January 1968

scopecontent.p: A script for the January 18 rehearsal, before the January 20 concert, with a cover letter to all participants from Millard Lampell.
The feature article in the Carnegie Hall magazine is "A Musical Tribute to Woody Guthrie."
Two copies of undated drawings by an unidentified artist.

did.unittitle:
Folk Song '59: Carnegie Hall program,
April 3, 1959

scopecontent.p: Two copies.
Four tickets for the second-tier box
Three receipts for payment for their performance at the concert: Muddy Waters (McKinley Morganfield), Mike Seeger, and Memphis Slim.

did.unittitle:
Telegram from Logan English to Alan Lomax and Lou Gordon,
April 3, 1959

scopecontent.p: Logan English sends congratulations on the evening of the Folk Song '59 concert.

did.unittitle:
Folk Song '59: announcement of the commercial recording,
April 4, 1959

scopecontent.p: A clipping from Cash Box, announcing an upcoming commercial release by United Artists of the concert.

did.unittitle:
A Musical Tribute to Woody Guthrie: Bound for Glory,
March 17, 1956

scopecontent.p: Woody Guthrie takes a bow. "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.
Woody Guthrie standing and possibly speaking; Nora Guthrie seated at far left. "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.

Left to right: Tom Clancy, Lou Gordon, Pat Clancy, Robin Roberts, and Phil Raiguel. Photographed by George Pickow. In performance at Cherry Lane Theatre, New York. PH03 and PH04 are the same image, with more or less the same details (due to how the images were printed).
See description for PH03.

Seated, left to right: Tom Clancy, Jean Ritchie, and Oscar Brand. Standing: Pat Clancy. In performance during a Swapping Song Fair concert. Photographed by George Pickow. Cherry Lane Theatre, New York.
Left to right: unidentified bagpiper and Robin Roberts. In performance during a Swapping Song Fair concert, Cherry Lane Theatre, New York.
Oscar Brand and Jean Ritchie. In performance during a Swapping Song Fair concert. Photographed by George Pickow. Cherry Lane Theatre, New York.
Left to right: Lou Gordon, Oscar Brand, and Jean Ritchie. In performance during a Swapping Song Fair concert. Photographed by George Pickow. Cherry Lane Theatre, New York.
Left to right: Pat Clancy, Oscar Brand, Jean Ritchie, and Tom Clancy. In performance during a Swapping Song Fair concert. Photographed by George Pickow. Cherry Lane Theatre, New York.
Lee Hays and Earl Robinson. At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.
Left to right: Lee Hays, Earl Robinson, Pete Seeger, and Robin Roberts. At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.

Foreground: Pete Seeger. Background, left to right: Earl Robinson, Robin Roberts (obscured), and Jimmy Gavin. At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.

Left to right: Ed McCurdy, the Kossoy Sisters (partially obscured), Pete Seeger, Robin Roberts, and Erik Darling (?). At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.

Left to right: Ed McCurdy, the Kossoy Sisters (partially obscured), Pete Seeger (obscured), Robin Roberts, Rev. Gary Davis, Earl Robinson, and Erik Darling (?). At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.
Rev. Gary Davis. At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.
Left to right: Rev. Gary Davis, Earl Robinson, and Erik Darling (?). At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.
Foregrand: Ed McCurdy. Lee Hays may be in the background. At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.

Left to right: Nora Guthrie, Toshi Seeger, Arlo Guthrie, Woody Guthrie, and Marjorie Guthrie (?). At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.
Seated: Pete Seeger. Standing: the Kossoy Sisters. At the "Bound for Glory" tribute concert to honor Woody Guthrie, held at the Pythian Temple, New York.
Folk Song '59, held at Carnegie Hall, New York.

Folk Song '59, held at Carnegie Hall, New York.
Publicity photo of Robin Roberts.
Publicity photo of Jean Ritchie.
Cisco Houston, in performance.

did.physdesc: 8 in. x 10 in. (the sheet); 3 in. x 3 in. (each image)

scopecontent.p: Swapping Song Fair. Images include Oscar Brand, Frank Warner, Pat Clancy, Phil Raguel, and Robin Roberts. Photographed by George Pickow. Black-and-white contact sheet with 11 frames; possibly shot with 120mm film.
